node.title: Amazon’s cloud computing outage disrupts its warehouse operations.
node.alt: Workers at an Amazon center. Company warehouses around the country stopped operating Tuesday as a result of disruptions in the company’s cloud computing system
node.description: Amazon Web Services began reporting increased “error rates” in its cloud operations on Tuesday morning.
node.content: ["SEATTLE \u2014 Amazon warehouses around the country stopped operating Tuesday as outages in the company\u2019s cloud computing system took down the technology that powers the company\u2019s logistics operations.", "The disruption came during the peak holiday season, with Amazon already dealing with more complicated and expensive logistics during a labor shortage. Usually, Amazon\u2019s share of online sales grows practically each day closer to Christmas.", "Amazon Web Services began reporting increased \u201cerror rates\u201d in its cloud operations on Tuesday morning. Amazon uses its own cloud services as the backbone for its operations, and workers across the country reported that the scanners and other systems that they used to process products had stopped working.", "\u201cThe A.W.S. team is working to resolve the issue as quickly as possible,\u201d Richard Rocha, an Amazon spokesman, said in a statement. Some problems persisted into Tuesday evening.", "On Facebook and other online forums, workers shared hundreds of status updates. Some said managers had sent them on their lunch breaks an hour early, in the hopes that the problems would be resolved by the time they returned. Others said their managers asked them to sweep floors, or offered unpaid time off to people who wanted to leave early. Many said they were just waiting around.", "\u201cSome people playing cornhole up by the time clocks and some are chilling in the break room,\u201d one employee in the Midwest wrote on Facebook.", "Companies that rely on Amazon\u2019s cloud computing experienced interruptions as well. Customers have reported problems with Roomba vacuum cleaners, Amazon\u2019s Alexa voice assistant and Disney\u2019s streaming service. Ticketmaster said it was delaying the presale of tickets for Adele\u2019s tour.", "About 6 p.m., Amazon\u2019s cloud computing division said, \u201cMany services have already recovered, however, we are working toward full recovery across services.\u201d"]
